Question: So tell me what exactly is Spring framework and why people use it
Answer: Spring is a framework that makes Java development easier and it helps in managing objects and dependencies and reduces boilerplate code

Question: Before Spring how people usually managed objects and why Spring became popular
Answer: Earlier developers created objects manually using new keyword and Spring made it easier by managing object creation and wiring

Question: People say Spring is lightweight so what does that mean
Answer: It means Spring does not force heavy configuration and we can use only what we need

Question: Can you explain what is IoC in simple words
Answer: IoC means control of object creation is given to Spring instead of developer

Question: So what is dependency injection in your own words
Answer: Dependency injection means Spring gives required objects to a class instead of class creating them itself

Question: Why dependency injection is better than using new keyword everywhere
Answer: It makes code loosely coupled and easy to test and easy to change

Question: What is Spring container and what does it do
Answer: Spring container creates objects manages them and injects dependencies

Question: Have you heard about Bean so what exactly is a Bean in Spring
Answer: Bean is simply an object that is created and managed by Spring container

Question: What is ApplicationContext in Spring
Answer: ApplicationContext is an advanced container that manages beans and provides many extra features

Question: What is difference between BeanFactory and ApplicationContext
Answer: ApplicationContext is more powerful and used in real applications while BeanFactory is basic

Question: How does Spring know which class it should create object for
Answer: Spring uses configuration either XML or annotations to know which classes are beans

Question: You used annotations in Spring so why annotations are helpful
Answer: Annotations reduce configuration and make code cleaner and easier to understand

Question: What is @Component annotation used for
Answer: It tells Spring that this class should be managed as a bean

Question: What is @Autowired and why we use it
Answer: @Autowired is used to tell Spring to inject dependency automatically

Question: What is scope of bean and which scope you mostly use
Answer: Scope defines how many objects Spring creates and mostly we use singleton scope

Question: Explain this code @Component class A {} what will Spring do
Answer: Spring will create object of this class and manage it as a bean

Question: What will happen in this code @Component class A { @Autowired B b; }
Answer: Spring will automatically find B bean and inject it into A

Question: Explain this code ApplicationContext ctx=new ClassPathXmlApplicationContext(config.xml)
Answer: Spring will load configuration file and create all defined beans

Question: What will happen if Spring does not find bean for @Autowired
Answer: Application will fail at startup because dependency is not satisfied

Question: Explain this code @Component class A { A(){ System.out.println(hi); } }
Answer: It will print hi when Spring creates object of this class

Question: What will this code do @Component class A { @PostConstruct void init(){ } }
Answer: This method will run after bean is created and dependencies are injected

Question: Explain this code @Component @Scope(prototype) class A {}
Answer: Spring will create new object every time this bean is requested

Question: What will happen in this code @Autowired private A a without @Component on A
Answer: Spring will not find bean and application will fail

Question: Explain this code context.getBean(A.class)
Answer: It will return object of class A from Spring container

Question: What will happen if two beans of same type exist and we use @Autowired
Answer: Spring will get confused and will throw exception unless we specify which one to use

Question: In real projects how does Spring actually manage object creation and lifecycle
Answer: Spring creates objects using container then injects dependencies then manages their full lifecycle from creation till destruction

Question: Why people say Spring promotes loose coupling and how you have seen it in code
Answer: Because classes do not create their own dependencies and Spring injects them so we can change implementation without changing main code

Question: What is difference between constructor injection and field injection and which one you prefer
Answer: Constructor injection makes dependencies mandatory and is better for testing while field injection is simpler but less safe

Question: In your project how do you usually configure Spring using XML or annotations and why
Answer: Mostly we use annotations because it reduces configuration and makes code more readable

Question: What problem does @Qualifier solve in real application
Answer: @Qualifier is used when multiple beans of same type exist and we want to tell Spring exactly which one to inject

Question: Can you explain bean lifecycle in simple steps
Answer: First Spring creates bean then injects dependencies then calls init methods and at shutdown it calls destroy methods

Question: What is singleton bean problem in multithreading and how Spring handles it
Answer: Singleton bean is shared by all threads so we must write thread safe code and Spring does not make it thread safe automatically

Question: When do you choose prototype scope instead of singleton
Answer: When we need a new object every time and object holds request specific data

Question: What is lazy initialization and why it is useful
Answer: Lazy initialization means bean is created only when needed and it reduces startup time

Question: What is difference between @Component and @Service or @Repository
Answer: All are same for Spring but they are used for better code understanding and special behaviors like exception translation

Question: How does Spring find all annotated classes without listing them
Answer: Spring scans packages using component scanning and finds annotated classes automatically

Question: What is Spring Expression Language and where it is used
Answer: It is used to read values and do small logic inside configuration

Question: What is @Primary and when do you use it
Answer: @Primary is used to tell Spring which bean should be chosen by default when multiple beans exist

Question: How do you read values from application properties file in Spring
Answer: We use @Value annotation or configuration properties class to read values

Question: What is difference between ApplicationContext and BeanFactory in real usage
Answer: ApplicationContext loads all beans at startup and provides many extra features so it is used in real projects

Question: Explain this code @Component class A { @Autowired public A(B b){ } }
Answer: Spring will use constructor injection and will inject B object when creating A

Question: What will happen in this code @Autowired private A a when there are two beans of A
Answer: Spring will throw error because it does not know which one to choose

Question: Explain this code @Bean public A getA(){ return new A(); }
Answer: Spring will call this method and store returned object as a bean

Question: What will happen in this code @Lazy @Component class A {}
Answer: Bean will not be created at startup and will be created only when requested

Question: Explain this code @PostConstruct public void init(){ System.out.println(start); }
Answer: This method will run after dependencies are injected and before bean is used

Question: What will happen in this code @PreDestroy public void destroy(){ }
Answer: This method will run when Spring container is shutting down

Question: Explain this code @Qualifier(fast) @Autowired Engine e
Answer: Spring will inject bean named fast into this variable

Question: What will happen in this code context.getBean(A.class) when no such bean exists
Answer: Spring will throw exception because bean is not found

Question: Explain this code @ComponentScan(basePackages=com.app)
Answer: Spring will scan this package and register all annotated classes as beans

Question: What will happen if you put @Autowired on setter method
Answer: Spring will call that setter and inject dependency through it

Question: Your Spring application fails at startup because of circular dependency so how will you fix it
Answer: I will break the dependency by introducing interface or using setter injection or redesigning the classes

Question: What actually happens when Spring creates a proxy object
Answer: Spring creates a wrapper object around real object and calls go through proxy before reaching actual method

Question: Why Spring uses proxy for AOP and transactions
Answer: Spring uses proxy so it can add extra behavior like transaction or logging without changing business code

Question: In which situation AOP will not work in Spring
Answer: It will not work when method is called from same class because call does not go through proxy

Question: What is difference between JDK proxy and CGLIB proxy
Answer: JDK proxy works with interfaces and CGLIB works with classes by creating subclass

Question: Your @Transactional is not working so what all things you will check
Answer: First I will check if method is public and if call is coming from another class and if proxy is created

Question: What problem does propagation in transaction solve
Answer: Propagation decides how new transaction should behave if one already exists

Question: What is isolation level and why it matters
Answer: Isolation level controls how data is visible between concurrent transactions

Question: Your application is slow at startup so how will you analyze Spring context loading
Answer: I will enable debug logs and check which beans are taking more time to initialize

Question: What is difference between ApplicationContext and WebApplicationContext
Answer: WebApplicationContext is special context used in web applications and has web related features

Question: Have you used multiple Spring contexts and why
Answer: Yes in large applications we use parent child context to separate core and web beans

Question: What happens if bean creation fails in middle of context startup
Answer: Spring will stop startup and destroy already created beans

Question: How do you debug BeanCreationException in real projects
Answer: I check full stack trace and root cause and then check which dependency is missing or failing

Question: Why field injection is not recommended in large projects
Answer: Because it makes testing difficult and hides dependencies

Question: What is difference between eager and lazy initialization in big applications
Answer: Eager loads everything at startup and lazy loads when needed so startup time is reduced

Question: What happens internally when you use @ComponentScan
Answer: Spring scans classpath finds annotated classes and registers them in context

Question: How do you control which beans should be loaded in which environment
Answer: We use profiles to load different beans for different environments

Question: Your production bug is not reproducible locally so how Spring profiles help
Answer: Profiles allow using same code with different configuration so we can simulate production environment

Question: What is FactoryBean and when do you need it
Answer: FactoryBean is used when bean creation logic is complex and needs custom code

Question: What is difference between BeanFactoryPostProcessor and BeanPostProcessor
Answer: One modifies bean definitions before creation and other modifies bean after creation

Question: How do you hook into Spring lifecycle to add custom logic
Answer: We can use BeanPostProcessor or lifecycle annotations

Question: What is self invocation problem in Spring AOP
Answer: When a method inside class calls another method of same class proxy is bypassed so AOP does not work

Question: Why Spring transactions do not work on private methods
Answer: Because proxy can only override public methods

Question: What happens if two beans depend on each other with constructor injection
Answer: Spring cannot resolve it and will throw circular dependency error

Question: How do you design Spring configuration for very large application
Answer: We split configuration into modules use profiles use multiple contexts and keep things loosely coupled
